note_content.History of Present Illness: Patient reports chronic back pain worsening over the past 6 months, not alleviated by over-the-counter medications.
note_content.Past Medical History: History of hypertension, controlled with medication.
note_content.Family History: Father had a history of osteoporosis.
note_content.Social History: Works as a software developer, sedentary lifestyle, non-smoker, occasional alcohol consumption.
note_content.Physical Examination: Limited range of motion in lower back, palpable tenderness in lumbar region, no apparent swelling.

Investigations.X-ray Findings: Lumbar spine x-ray shows mild disc degeneration at L3-L4.
Investigations.MRI Findings: MRI of the lumbar spine reveals a small central disc protrusion at L3-L4 without significant nerve root compression.

note_content.Problem: Chronic lower back pain likely due to disc degeneration.

Plan.Continue current hypertension medication: routine screening, and patient education on proper posture and ergonomics at work.

Radiology Discussion.Purpose of Investigations: To assess the integrity of the lumbar spine and identify potential causes of back pain.
Radiology Discussion.Findings Interpretation: Mild disc degeneration is consistent with the patient's symptoms but not severe enough for surgical intervention at this stage.
Radiology Discussion.Recommendations: Regular monitoring with follow-up imaging in 6 months or earlier if symptoms exacerbate.
